title: Toyota slashes as semis squeezed
text:
The wheels are coming off Toyota's so-far smooth ride through the global chip crisis, with the world's largest carmaker announcing on Thursday it would slash global production by 40 per cent next month.

The Japanese company reported a record quarterly profit only two weeks ago as it took advantage of US rivals' component shortages. Toyota was able to dip into a semiconductor stockpile it had built up, helped by the proximity of local chip producer Renesas

But now a combination of the chip shortage and Covid-19 hitting production for component suppliers in Vietnam and Malaysia has forced it to cut planned September production of 900,000 vehicles to 540,000.

Its shares fell more than 4 per cent on the news and Alphaville speculates that investors' fears about the brittleness of the global supply chain contributed to today's market falls.

In other chip news, Nvidia said overnight it was still “confident” of sealing its deal for semi designer Arm, but that delays in regulatory approvals are likely to push out the 18-month timetable for completion. There is speculation that this could prompt a rethink by owner SoftBank, which could opt for a stock market listing for Arm instead. Meanwhile, Nvidia's rival Intel has unveiled a new generation of chip architectures today.

The Internet of (Five) Things

1. Facebook faces fresh antitrust complaint . . . 
The US Federal Trade Commission has refiled its antitrust complaint against Facebook, doubling down on its accusations that it maintains monopoly power and uses a “buy or bury” strategy to neutralise competitors. Initially filed in December, the original lawsuit was dismissed by a federal judge in June who said it had “failed to plead enough facts”.

2 . . . but it's pressing ahead with a digital wallet
David Marcus, the executive who spearheaded the social media group's move into digital currencies, says Facebook is ready to launch a digital wallet. In a memo on Wednesday, Marcus said that Novi, a digital currency wallet that will be integrated into Facebook apps, had secured licences or regulatory approvals in “nearly every” US state. 

3. SEC sues Netflix engineers over insider trading
The US Securities and Exchange Commission has sued three former Netflix engineers over insider trading, alleging they made more than $3m in profits by trading on subscriber numbers before they were released publicly.

4. Ex-SEC chair believes in blockchain
Jay Clayton, the former SEC chair, has told us he believes both in the promise of blockchain technology and the need for more regulation for the crypto sector. He was speaking to the FT as he joined the advisory board of digital asset infrastructure provider Fireblocks. Elsewhere, US cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase has struck a deal with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, betting the Japanese bank's vast customer base will help it secure a foothold in one of the world's centres for digital asset trading. Lex has been looking at the Robinhood trading app's maiden results and says it has a long way to go for meaningful growth.

5. Gopuff raises $1bn, cuts workers' pay
Less than a month after it secured $1bn in venture capital, delivery app Gopuff has slashed pay for many of its gig workers to rates that sometimes fall below minimum wage after accounting for expenses, reports Dave Lee in San Francisco.

Forwarded from Sifted — the European start-up week

This week, Peter Thiel's investment fund Valar Ventures led a $263m funding round into the crypto trading platform Bitpanda, which valued the company at $4.1bn. It wasn't so much the size of the round that was remarkable, however. What was unusual was that the three founders still own 50 per cent of the company at this late stage, making them near billionaires. It's a sign of the sheer amount of money flowing into European start-ups at the moment but also the continuing excitement around the crypto market.

On the same theme of people getting rich in tech, Sifted reported this week that London-based fintech Revolut has turned more than 70 ordinary employees into paper millionaires from stock options in the $33bn company. Elsewhere, psychedelic toad venom could soon be a clinical treatment for depression, tech companies are offering free cars to attract employees and European start-ups have been flexing their muscles with a €1bn acquisition splurge.

Tech tools — Facebook's Horizon Workrooms

Facebook has unveiled part of its vision for the metaverse in the enterprise, with the launch of Horizon Workrooms, a new free Facebook app designed to allow employees to work together in a shared, imaginary office. Hannah Murphy took part in a virtual press conference on the new app that used the technology and Facebook's own Oculus virtual reality headsets. It allows workers to sit with colleagues, chat and collaborate using virtual whiteboards. “The idea is you go in, wherever you are, you can have your perfect set-up, people can stop in and collaborate quickly. But it's really great for focused work,” Zuckerberg — in avatar form — told reporters. “What we're trying to move towards is a world where a lot of what we do is in here . . . We think it's going to be a big use case for VR.”
